We have a dilemma which is
not peculiar to Hopkins but may
be found on campuses across the
country.
Briefly stated our problem
runs approximately thus: In the
face of general student apathy
to student government, what
must be done to insure the functioning of student government in
those areas in which it is required to serve? Before this
problem can be attacked,
it
must be ascertained exactly what
are the functions of the Student
Council. And before even this
can be approached, there must
be serious and lengthy debate
upon the real purpose of the
Student Council.
Re-Evaluation Called For

(1) That the new Student
Council should re-evaluate its
entire program..That the committee system which has existed
for years be changed to eliminate such obvious anachronisms
as the "Traffic Committee."
That the Student Council police
its own ranks so that whatever
course of action is decided as
necessary, enough members are
present to carry it to fruition.
(2) That the Council get down
to the business of really representing the student body to off
campus groups. That it poll the
student body when an issue
arises. I can cite two examples
of instances where the Council
failed to do this. One was when
we were asked by the Brandeis

started a sit-in movement and it

to
estimate
whether this really represented
the opinion of the Student Body.

the Council must act on the behalf of the entire student body
and to do so it must measure
student opinion.

review the relations of the Student Government with the Administration. To be rather blunt,

This year the Student Council
has been faced with a number of
serious problems that councils
in the past several years didn't
have to face. Many meetings
have been called off due to failure to obtain a quorum; activities have been planned and then
cancelled; true student opinion
has not been reflected; and
many meetings were wasted by
quibbling over the role of the
council with respect to other
organizations.
This was a unique year, for
this is the first time that the
Council has been needlessly plagued with being unable to plan
and execute a program of activities that truly have served the
entire student body and one that
has tried to boost school pride
and spirit.
Boost Needed
The most effective way to give
the student body a shot in the
arm for spirit boosting is to
give the council a shot in the
arm by solving the quorum problem. Poor attendance was caused
by several, members' beliefs that
the council was accomplishing
nothing and that there was no
opportunity for them to contribute to school projects.
If a good solid grasp of activities could be planned for this
spring by the new council, then
I believe the members would feel
that they had an opportunity
to contribute to the well-being
of the Homewood community,
and thus the quorum problem
would disappear.

plans for HOmecoming, spring
dances, parents day, interesting
assembly programs, and the
publication of a freshman handbook.

forum where the opinions of the
entire student body can be represented and not just the opinions of its members. For student
government organizations must

PROMOTIONS
The Johns Hopkins University
has announced the promotion of
three faculty members: Dr. Rene
Girard and Dr. Jun-Ichi Igusa

his Ph.D. degree at Indiana
Unisversity.

numer.ous articles in French and
American literary periodicals and

American Mathematical Society.
Psychologist

Wisconsin where he received his
B.A., M.A., and Ph.D. degrees.
He came to Hopkins as instructor of psychology in 1956.

In a recent learned journal (Mad) the distinguished board
chairman (Ralph "Hot-Lips" Sigafoos) of one of our most
important American corporations (the Arf Mechanical Dog Co.)
wrote a trenchant article in which he pinpointed our gravest
national problem: the lack of culture among science graduates.
Mr. Sigafoos's article, it must be emphasized, was in no sense
derogatory. He stated quite clearly that the science student,
what with his gruelling curriculum in physics, math, and chemistry, can hardly be expected to find time to study the arts
too. What Mr, Sigafoos deplores—indeed, what we all deplore
—is the lopsided result of today's science courses: graduates
Who can build a bridge but can't compose a concerto, who know
Planck's Constant but not Botticelli's Venus, who are familiar
with Fraunhofer's lines but not with Schiller's.
Mr. Sigafoos can find no solution to this hideous imbalance.
I, however, believe there is one—and a very simple one. It is
this: if students of s'cience don't have time. to come to the arts,
then we ihust fet the arts come to students of science.

For example, it would be a very easy thing to teach poetry
and music right along with physics. Students, instead of merely
being called upon to recite in physics class, would instead be
required to rhyme their answers and set them to familial tunes
—like, foll instance, The Colonel Bogey March. Thus recitations
Would not only be chock-full of important facts but would, at

great music. Here, try it yourself. You all know The Colonel

leaves the classroom and lights his Marlboro, how much more

This spring, as every other spring, each Hopkins
team will not reach its peak performance till half the
season is over, giving each of its opponents an advantage.
The blame can't be put on player or coach but rather
on the Baltimore weather and the complete absence of
indoor practice facilities at Hopkins. Only because of its
wealth of talent' have the lacrosse and tennis teams been
able to post their good reeords.
Each spring the story is the same; only a few details
change. Last year it snowed and this year it rained.

practices. With only enough room to hold three basketball
games on undersized courts, Homewood Gym doesn't provide the facilities needed for the more expansive sports
like lacrosse and baseball. With five teams, ten including
the freshman squads, clamoring for the much needed practice in the undersized gym with only two hours open, a
rainy day' can be considered a wasted day.

lacrosse team was forced to risk injury by practicing in
the iquagmire that was the lower field. The baseball team
was forced to retreat indoors to escape the cold that reeks
havoc on arms and legs that are seeking to get into shape.
In •order to get into shape in their closed quarters they
played volleyball, which is not too much like baseball.
As the first half of the spring sports season gets under
way, the Jays in all departments will be forced to compete against teams who gradually reached their top form
under the optimum conditions. What do they have that
we don't have? A field house where the track team can
run, the baseball team can have infield and pitching drills,
the lacrosse squad can have practice space and still leave
room to set up a tennis net. Many a fieldhouse raises
spectator sports emphasis.
It is about time that those who are concern'ed with
the future of Hopkins athletics think of providing better
facilities so that Jay teams can do battle at full strength.

Who can build a bridge but can't compose a concerto, who know

By JOEL GORDON
This spring, as every other spring, each Hopkins
team will not reach its peak performance till half the
season is over, giving each of its opponents an advantage.
The blame can't be put on player or coach but rather
on the Baltimore weather and the complete absence of
indoor practice facilities at Hopkins. Only because of its
wealth of talent' have the lacrosse and tennis teams been
able to post their good reeords.
Each spring the story is the same; only a few details
change. Last year it snowed and this year it rained.
Both years every team was forced to use the gym for
practices. With only enough room to hold three basketball
games on undersized courts, Homewood Gym doesn't provide the facilities needed for the more expansive sports
like lacrosse and baseball. With five teams, ten including
the freshman squads, clamoring for the much needed practice in the undersized gym with only two hours open, a
rainy day' can be considered a wasted day.
This year in order to prepare for its competition the
lacrosse team was forced to risk injury by practicing in
the iquagmire that was the lower field. The baseball team
was forced to retreat indoors to escape the cold that reeks
havoc on arms and legs that are seeking to get into shape.
In •order to get into shape in their closed quarters they
played volleyball, which is not too much like baseball.
As the first half of the spring sports season gets under
way, the Jays in all departments will be forced to compete against teams who gradually reached their top form
under the optimum conditions. What do they have that
we don't have? A field house where the track team can
run, the baseball team can have infield and pitching drills,
the lacrosse squad can have practice space and still leave
room to set up a tennis net. Many a fieldhouse raises
spectator sports emphasis.
It is about time that those who are concern'ed with
the future of Hopkins athletics think of providing better
facilities so that Jay teams can do battle at full strength.
